title: Heterometrus yaleensis
text:
Heterometrus yaleensis is a species of <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a> in the family <a href="Buthidae">Buthidae</a> endemic to <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>.
Etymology.
The species name is named after <a href="Yala%20National%20Park">Yala National Park</a>, the most visited and second largest national park in Sri Lanka. It is the region where both type specimens of the species were recorded.
Description.
The total length of males is 75 mm and 103 mm in female. The body is uniformly reddish brown to black in color. The <a href="telson">telson</a> appears yellowish to reddish brown. Legs are yellow to reddish brown but lighter than body. <a href="Chelicerae">Chelicerae</a> are yellow with dark reticulation. Anterior manus and fingers are reddish black. <a href="Pedipalps">Pedipalps</a> are orthobothriotaxic type C. There are 13 to 14 <a href="pectinal%20teeth">pectinal teeth</a>. In males, pedipalp <a href="chela%20%28organ%29">chela</a>, <a href="femur">femur</a> and <a href="patella">patella</a> are narrower and longer than in females. Chelae are lobiform and strongly tuberculate with pronounced <a href="Keel%20%28anatomy%29">carinae</a>. Patella of pedipalp consists of several small internal <a href="tubercles">tubercles</a>. <a href="Carapace">Carapace</a> appears smooth, and very sparsely granulated laterally. <a href="Tergites">Tergites</a> are smooth and do not exhibit carinae. Telson are hirsute and elongate. Telson vesicle is similar in size to aculeus.
